div.head: 295. Robert Bloomfield to John Glover, 3 November 1814BL Add. MS 30809, ff. 54–55
div.p: When I left you I had spent nearly all my money, and was in low spirits. If this had not been the case I would gladly have arranged matters so as to have had the painting and other things done, but when I tell you what I have paid, and you have compared it with the my [sic] receipts you will be a better judge of what ought to be expected from me so situated. While in Suffolk I paid to

row.cell: Mr Barker for attendance on my Mother
To Mr Austin for mending clay, whitewashing,
and work done to the well, and materials
Do—To straw and thatching two sheds at the
Or, properly speaking, for the House only

div.p: I cannot in my conscience ask the widow of my Brother to pay Rent. Yet the parish have assessed me in 8 shillings per year as Landlord’s property tax; this have been paid by Mr Mothersole for six years past, and I now find myself £2 s8 d0 in his debt. If you deduct 8 shillings per ann. from the only rent I receive you will leave me just 2 guineas a year to stand for simple interest of the value of the Cottage, and to stand to Repairs! If I was forced to sell the place and got, as I trust I could, £140, it would bring me £7 per ann. at common interest, and without deduction.—

What can be done in repairing a House out of two guineas per year? I therefore think that no one can think me unreasonable if I expect for the future that the occupiers should pay the Tax, which for the three tenements, and gathered half yearly, would amount to sixteen pence a piece only.

My affairs are by no means flourishing, but I hope I shall be able to keep the place till I dies, but further repairs now, or for some time to come would not at all, suit my pockets or perhaps be prudent in any way. You must wait, and so must I for better prospects, I am perfectly satisfied with what you have done, and wish I could do more

closer.salute: Love to Sister Bet and Children and I am yours sincerely

postscript.p: P.S. I did not learn from Mr Mothersole that he had paid the tax until the very day before I left Honington.
